conclusion: Understanding how shadows change when the light source moves to the right and directly above the objects.
The light source is currently positioned to the left of the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Shadows A and B are cast by the objects on the right side of the light source.
Shadows C and D are cast by the objects on the left side of the light source.
The light source is moved to the right and directly above the objects.
When the light source is directly above the objects, the shadows will be cast directly below the objects.
The size and location of the shadows will depend on the distance and angle of the objects relative to the light source.
Shadow A will be reduced in size and may disappear if the object is small enough or if the angle of the object is such that it does not block the light.
Shadow B will be reduced in size and may disappear under the same conditions as shadow A.
Shadow C will be reduced in size and may disappear when the light source is directly above.
Shadow D will be reduced in size and may disappear under the same conditions as shadow C.
If the objects are small enough or if the angle of the objects is such that they do not block the light, the shadows may completely disappear.
If the objects are large enough or if the angle of the objects is such that they block the light, the shadows will still be present but will be smaller and may be in different locations.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will be reduced in size and may disappear if the objects are small enough or if the angle of the objects is such that they do not block the light.
If the objects are large enough or if the angle of the objects is such that they block the light, the shadows will still be present but will be smaller and may be in different locations.
